home.title: Learn Java
paragraphs: Java is a popular programming language.
Java is used to develop mobile apps, web apps, desktop apps, games and much more.
Start learning Java now »

sections.heading: Tip
paragraphs: Tip: Sign in to track your progress.

sections.heading: Examples in Each Chapter
paragraphs: Our "Try it Yourself" editor makes it easy to learn Java. You can edit Java code and view the result in your browser.

example.title: Example

sections.heading: Reading Order
paragraphs: We recommend reading this tutorial, in the sequence listed in the left menu.
Java is an object oriented language and some concepts may be new. Take breaks when needed, and go over the examples as many times as needed.

sections.heading: Java Exercises
paragraphs: Many chapters in this tutorial end with an exercise where you can check your level of knowledge.

exercise.question:
Drag and drop the correct method to print Hello World in Java.
System.out. ("Hello World");

sections.heading: Java Quiz
paragraphs: Test your Java skills with a quiz.

sections.heading: Learn by Examples
paragraphs: Learn by examples! This tutorial supplements all explanations with clarifying examples.

sections.heading: Track Your Progress
paragraphs: Create a W3Schools account and get access to more features and learning materials:
list: View your completed tutorials, exercises, and quizzes
Keep an eye on your progress and daily streaks
Join the leaderboard and compete with others
Get your own avatar and unlock new skins
sections.note: Note: This is an optional feature. You can study at W3Schools without creating an account.

sections.heading: Java Reference
paragraphs: You will also find complete keyword and method references:

sections.heading: Kickstart your career
paragraphs: Get certified by completing the JAVA course

sections.heading: What is Java?
paragraphs: Java is a popular and powerful programming language, created in 1995.
It is owned by Oracle, and more than 3 billion devices run Java.

sections.heading: Why Use Java?
list: Java works on different platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, Raspberry Pi, etc.)
It is one of the most popular programming languages in the world
It has a large demand in the current job market
It is easy to learn and simple to use
It is secure, fast and powerful
It has huge community support (tens of millions of developers)
Java is an object oriented language which gives a clear structure to programs and allows code to be reused, lowering development costs
As Java is close to C++ and C#, it makes it easy for programmers to switch to Java or vice versa

sections.heading: Java Example
paragraphs: Java is often used in everyday programming tasks, like saying hello to a user:

example.title: Example

sections.heading: Get Started
paragraphs: By the end of this tutorial, you will know how to write basic Java programs and apply your skills to real-life examples.
You don't need any prior programming experience - just curiosity and practice!

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Introduction

sections.heading: Get Started With Java
paragraphs: At W3Schools, you can try Java without installing anything.
Our Online Java Editor runs directly in your browser, and shows both the code and the result:

example.label: Code

paragraphsAfterExample: This editor will be used in the entire tutorial to demonstrate the different aspects of Java.

sections.heading: Java Install
paragraphs: However, if you want to run Java on your own computer, follow the instructions below.
Some PCs might have Java already installed.
To check if you have Java installed on a Windows PC, search in the start bar for Java or type the following in Command Prompt (cmd.exe):
paragraphsAfterCode: If Java is installed, you will see something like this (depending on version):
sections.outputExample:
java version "22.0.0" 2024-08-21 LTS
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment 22.9 (build 22.0.0+13-LTS)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 22.9 (build 22.0.0+13-LTS, mixed mode)
paragraphsAfterOutput: If you do not have Java installed on your computer, you can download it at oracle.com.

Note: In this tutorial, we will write Java code in a text editor. However, it is possible to write Java in an Integrated Development Environment, such as IntelliJ IDEA, Netbeans or Eclipse, which are particularly useful when managing larger collections of Java files.

sections.heading: Java Quickstart
paragraphs: In Java, every application begins with a class name, and that class must match the filename.
Let's create our first Java file, called Main.java, which can be done in any text editor (like Notepad).
The file should contain a "Hello World" message, which is written with the following code:

example.label: Main.java

paragraphsAfterExample: Don't worry if you don't understand the code above - we will discuss it in detail in later chapters. For now, focus on how to run the code above.
Save the code in Notepad as "Main.java". Open Command Prompt (cmd.exe), navigate to the directory where you saved your file, and type "javac Main.java":
paragraphsAfterSteps: This will compile your code. If there are no errors in the code, the command prompt will take you to the next line. Now, type "java Main" to run the file:
Congratulations! You have written and executed your first Java program.

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Get Started

sections.heading: Java Syntax
paragraphs: In the previous chapter, we created a Java file called Main.java, and we used the following code to print "Hello World" to the screen:

example.title: Example
example.label: Main.java

sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: Every line of code that runs in Java must be inside a class. The class name should always start with an uppercase first letter. In our example, we named the class Main.
Note: Java is case-sensitive. MyClass and myclass would be treated as two completely different names.

The name of the Java file must match the class name. So if your class is called Main, the file must be saved as Main.java. This is because Java uses the class name to find and run your code. If the names don't match, Java will give an error and the program will not run.
When saving the file, save it using the class name and add .java to the end of the filename.
To run the example above on your computer, make sure that Java is properly installed: Go to the Get Started Chapter for how to install Java.
The output should be:
Hello World

sections.heading: The main Method
paragraphs: The main() method is required in every Java program. It is where the program starts running:
paragraphsAfterCode: Any code placed inside the main() method will be executed.
For now, you don't need to understand the keywords public, static, and void. You will learn about them later in this tutorial.
Just remember: main() is the starting point of every Java program.

sections.heading: System.out.println()
paragraphs: Inside the main() method, we can use the println() method to print a line of text to the screen:

example.title: Example

sections.note: Note: The curly braces {} mark the beginning and the end of a block of code.
paragraphsAfterExample: System.out.println() may look long, but you can think of it as a single command that means: "Send this text to the screen."
Here's what each part means (you will learn the details later):
list: System is a built-in Java class.
out is a member of System, short for "output".
println() is a method, short for "print line".
paragraphsAfterList: Finally, remember that each Java statement must end with a semicolon (;).

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct class name to match the file name Main.java.

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Syntax

sections.heading: Print Text
paragraphs: You learned from the previous chapter that you can use the println() method to output values or print text in Java:

example.title: Example
example.code: System.out.println("Hello World!");

sections.heading: Multiple println()
paragraphs: You can add as many println() methods as you want. Note that it will add a new line for each method:

example.title: Example

sections.heading: Double Quotes
paragraphs: Text must be wrapped inside double quotations marks "".
If you forget the double quotes, an error occurs:

example.title: Example
example.code:
System.out.println("This sentence will work!");
System.out.println(This sentence will produce an error);

sections.heading: The print() Method
paragraphs: There is also a print() method, which is similar to println().
The only difference is that it does not insert a new line at the end of the output:

example.title: Example
example.code:
System.out.print("Hello World! ");
System.out.print("I will print on the same line.");

paragraphsAfterExample: Note that we add an extra space (after "Hello World!" in the example above) for better readability.
In this tutorial, we will only use println() as it makes the code output easier to read.

exercise.question:
Drag and drop the correct method to print Hello World in Java.
System.out.("Hello World");

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Output / Print

sections.heading: Java Comments
paragraphs: Comments can be used to explain Java code, and to make it more readable.
It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by Java (will not be executed).
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code:
// This is a comment
System.out.println("Hello World");

sections.heading: Single-line Comment at End of Line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code: System.out.println("Hello World"); // This is a comment

sections.heading: Java Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by Java.
This example uses a multi-line comment (a comment block) to explain the code:

example.title: Example

sections.heading: Single or multi-line comments?
paragraphs: It's up to you which one you use.
Normally, we use // for short comments, and /* */ for longer.

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct syntax for a single-line comment in Java.

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Comments

sections.heading: Java Variables
paragraphs: Variables are containers for storing data values.

sections.heading: Variable Types
paragraphs: In Java, there are different types of variables, for example:
list: String - stores text, such as "Hello". String values are surrounded by double quotes
int - stores integers (whole numbers), without decimals, such as 123 or -123
float - stores floating point numbers, with decimals, such as 19.99 or -19.99
char - stores single characters, such as 'a' or 'B'. Char values are surrounded by single quotes
boolean - stores values with two states: true or false

sections.heading: Declaring (Creating) Variables
paragraphs: To create a variable in Java, you need to:
list: Choose a type (like int or String)
Give the variable a name (like x, age, or name)
Optionally assign it a value using =

sections.heading: String Example
paragraphs: Create a variable called name of type String and assign it the value "John".
Then we use println() to print the name variable:

example.code:
String name = "John";
System.out.println(name);

sections.heading: int Example
paragraphs: Create a variable called myNum of type int and assign it the value 15:

example.code:
int myNum = 15;
System.out.println(myNum);

sections.heading: Declare Then Assign
paragraphs: You can also declare a variable without assigning the value, and assign the value later:

sections.heading: Overwrite Value
paragraphs: Note that if you assign a new value to an existing variable, it will overwrite the previous value:

sections.heading: Final Variables
paragraphs: If you don't want others (or yourself) to overwrite existing values, use the final keyword (this will declare the variable as "final" or "constant", which means unchangeable and read-only):

example.code:
final int myNum = 15;
myNum = 20;  // will generate an error: cannot assign a value to a final variable

sections.heading: Other Types
paragraphs: A demonstration of how to declare variables of other types:
paragraphsAfterExample: You will learn more about data types in the next section.

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct data type to declare an integer variable.

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Variables

sections.heading: Java Data Types
paragraphs: As explained in the previous chapter, a variable in Java must be a specified data type:

example.title: Example
example.code:
int myNum = 5;               // Integer (whole number)
float myFloatNum = 5.99f;    // Floating point number
char myLetter = 'D';         // Character
boolean myBool = true;       // Boolean
String myText = "Hello";     // String

sections.heading: Data Types Groups
paragraphs: Data types are divided into two groups:
list: Primitive data types - includes byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean and char
Non-primitive data types - such as String, Arrays and Classes (you will learn more about these in a later chapter)

sections.heading: Primitive Data Types
paragraphs: A primitive data type specifies the type of a variable and the kind of values it can hold.
There are eight primitive data types in Java:

table.description: Stores whole numbers from -128 to 127
Stores whole numbers from -32,768 to 32,767
Stores whole numbers from -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647
Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for storing 6 to 7 decimal digits
Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for storing 15 to 16 decimal digits
Stores true or false values
Stores a single character/letter or ASCII values

sections.heading: You Cannot Change the Type
paragraphs: Once a variable is declared with a type, it cannot change to another type later in the program:

example.title: Example

sections.note: Note: This rule makes Java safer, because the compiler will stop you if you try to mix up types by mistake.
paragraphsAfterNote: If you really need to change between types, you must use type casting or conversion methods (for example, turning an int into a double).

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct integer value to complete the code.

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Data Types

sections.heading: Java Type Casting
paragraphs: Type casting means converting one data type into another. For example, turning an int into a double.
In Java, there are two main types of casting:
list: Widening Casting (automatic) - converting a smaller type to a larger type size
byte -> short -> char -> int -> long -> float -> double
Narrowing Casting (manual) - converting a larger type to a smaller type size
double -> float -> long -> int -> char -> short -> byte

sections.heading: Widening Casting
paragraphs: Widening casting is done automatically when passing a smaller size type into a larger size type.
This works because there is no risk of losing information. For example, an int value can safely fit inside a double:

example.title: Example
example.code:
int myInt = 9;
double myDouble = myInt; // Automatic casting: int to double

System.out.println(myInt);    // Outputs 9
System.out.println(myDouble); // Outputs 9.0

sections.heading: Narrowing Casting
paragraphs: Narrowing casting must be done manually by placing the type in parentheses () in front of the value.
This is required because narrowing may result in data loss (for example, dropping decimals when converting a double to an int):

example.title: Example
example.code:
double myDouble = 9.78d;
int myInt = (int) myDouble; // Manual casting: double to int

System.out.println(myDouble); // Outputs 9.78
System.out.println(myInt);    // Outputs 9

sections.heading: Real-Life Example
paragraphs: Here is a real-life example of type casting. We calculate the percentage of a user's score in relation to the maximum score in a game.
We use type casting to make sure that the result is a floating-point value, rather than an integer:

example.title: Example

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct value to show widening casting (automatic type conversion).

sections.heading: Video
paragraphs: Video: Java Type Casting

java_projects.title: Java Projects
intro: Learn how to apply your Java knowledge to real-world projects.
This section focuses on building small applications using concepts learned throughout the tutorial.

sections.heading: Why Build Projects?
paragraphs: Projects are an essential part of learning Java.
Start small and gradually add more features to improve understanding.
list: Understand how real programs are structured
Practice combining concepts like methods, loops, and file handling
Prepare for job interviews and practical exercises
sections.tip: The more you build, the better you understand.

sections.heading: Beginner Project Ideas
paragraphs: Start with very small projects that use basic input and output.
examples: Print: Hi <name>! You will turn <age+1> next year.

sections.heading: Intermediate Project Ideas
paragraphs: Once comfortable, combine loops, conditions, and arrays.

sections.heading: Advanced Project Ideas
paragraphs: Move on to projects that use methods, classes, and file handling.

sections.heading: Project: Calculate a Student's Average
description: This project calculates the average of multiple grades entered by the user.
It then displays the average and a corresponding letter grade.

sections.heading: Practice Challenge
challenge: Ask the user to enter up to 5 shopping items
Store the items in an array
Count how many items were entered
sections.extra_challenge: Add a search feature that checks whether an item exists in the list.

sections.heading: Tips for Practice
paragraphs: Use your favorite Java IDE such as IntelliJ IDEA or VS Code.
Start small, add one feature at a time, and test your code often.
Use Java How To pages for step-by-step guidance.

sections.heading: Overview
paragraphs: This section contains Java reference documentation.
It provides quick access to Java keywords and commonly used classes and methods.

sections.heading: Java Keywords
paragraphs: Java has a set of reserved keywords that cannot be used as identifiers such as variable names, method names, or class names.

table.description: Used with classes and methods that are incomplete and must be implemented by subclasses

Prevents modification or inheritance

Implements an interface
Imports classes or packages

Integer data type

Long integer data type
Creates a new object
Groups related classes and interfaces
Restricts access within the same class
Allows access in the same package or subclasses

Returns a value from a method
Belongs to the class rather than objects

Type inference for local variables (Java 10+)

sections.heading: Notes
paragraphs: true, false, and null are literals, not keywords, but they are reserved and cannot be used as identifiers.

paragraphs: The Java Math class provides static methods to perform mathematical operations on numbers.

sections.heading: Notes
paragraphs: All Math methods are static.

sections.heading: Output Methods
paragraphs: The System.out stream (short for "output") is used with different methods to output values or print text to the console.

table.description: Prints text or values to the console
Prints formatted text or values to the console
Prints text or values to the console, followed by a new line

sections.heading: Arrays Class
paragraphs: The Java Arrays class (found in java.util) provides static methods that allow you to manipulate arrays.

sections.heading: Arrays Methods
paragraphs: A list of popular methods of the Arrays class can be found in the table below.

table.description: Compares two arrays
Creates a copy of an array with a new length
Compares two multidimensional arrays for deep equality
Checks if two arrays are equal
Fills an array with a specified value
Returns the index of the first mismatch between two arrays
Sorts an array in ascending order

sections.heading: Properties
paragraphs: The length property is a built-in Java property and does not belong to the Arrays class.

table.description: Returns the length of an array

paragraphs: The Scanner class can be used to obtain data from the keyboard, files and strings.

sections.heading: File Class Methods
paragraphs: The File class (from java.io) is used to work with file and directory paths. It lets you create, delete, and get information about files and folders, but it does not read or write the contents.

Tests whether the application can execute the file

sections.heading: FileInputStream Methods
paragraphs: The FileInputStream class provides methods to read data (as bytes) from a file:

table.description: Returns the number of bytes that can be read without blocking
Closes the stream and releases system resources
Reads one byte of data

table.method: read(byte[] b, int off, int len)
table.description: Reads bytes into an array or a portion of an array
Skips over and discards n bytes of data
Returns the file descriptor object associated with the stream
Returns the unique FileChannel object for this stream

sections.heading: FileOutputStream Methods
paragraphs: The FileOutputStream class provides methods to write data (as bytes) to a file:

table.description: Closes the stream and releases system resources
Flushes the stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written immediately
Writes one byte, an array of bytes, or part of an array to the file
Returns the file descriptor object associated with the stream
Returns the unique FileChannel object for this stream

sections.heading: BufferedReader Methods
paragraphs: The BufferedReader class provides methods to read text efficiently:

table.description: Closes the stream and releases system resources
Marks the current position in the stream
Checks if mark() and reset() are supported
Reads a single character

table.method: read(char[] cbuf, int off, int len)
table.description: Reads characters into an array or a portion of an array
Reads one full line of text
Checks if the stream is ready to be read
Resets the stream to the last marked position
Skips over characters in the stream
Returns a Stream<String> of all lines
Reads all characters and writes them to the given writer

sections.heading: BufferedWriter Methods
paragraphs: The BufferedWriter class provides methods to write text efficiently:

table.description: Closes the stream, flushing it first
Forces any buffered output to be written immediately
Writes the system's line separator

table.cription: Writes a single character, an array, a portion of an array, a string, or part of a string

table.description: Appends characters or character sequences to the writer

sections.heading: Iterator Methods
paragraphs: The Iterator interface provides methods to access and iterate through collections:

table.description: Returns true if there are more elements in the iteration
Returns the next element in the iteration
Removes the last element returned by next()

sections.note: Note: The next() method uses the type of the iterator's items as its return value. This type is referred to as T in the table.

sections.heading: Collections Methods
paragraphs: The Collections class (in java.util) contains several useful methods for working with collections like ArrayList, HashSet, and HashMap.

table.description: Sorts the list in ascending order (according to natural ordering)
Searches for a key in a sorted list and returns its index (otherwise < 0)
Reverses the order of elements in a list
Returns a comparator that imposes the reverse of natural ordering
Randomly permutes the elements of a list
Swaps the elements at the specified positions in a list
Returns the number of elements equal to the specified object
Returns the maximum element of a collection (according to natural ordering)
Returns the minimum element of a collection (according to natural ordering)
Checks if two collections have no elements in common
Copies all elements from one list into another
Replaces all elements of the list with the specified object
Replaces all occurrences of one value with another in a list
Returns an unmodifiable (read-only) view of the specified list
Returns an unmodifiable (read-only) view of the specified set
Returns an unmodifiable (read-only) view of the specified map

sections.heading: System Methods
paragraphs: The System class contains several useful methods for input, output, properties, time, and memory management.

table.description: Returns the current time in milliseconds since January 1, 1970 (Unix epoch)
Returns the current value of the most precise available system timer, in nanoseconds
Terminates the running Java program. A nonzero status indicates abnormal termination
Suggests that the Java Virtual Machine run the garbage collector
Gets the system property indicated by the key, or returns the default value if not found
Returns all system properties as a Properties object
Sets the system property indicated by the key
Removes the system property indicated by the key
Copies elements from the source array into the destination array
Returns the default hash code of the given object (even if hashCode() is overridden)
Returns the system-dependent line separator string (e.g. \"\\n\" on Linux, \"\\r\\n\" on Windows)
Returns an unmodifiable map of the system environment variables
Returns the value of the specified environment variable, or null if it does not exist
Standard input stream (usually the keyboard)
Standard output stream (usually the console). Often used with println()
Standard error output stream (usually the console)

sections.heading: Errors and Exception Types
paragraphs: The table below shows a list of common Error and Exception types in Java:

table.name: ArithmeticError
table.description: Occurs when a numeric calculation goes wrong

table.name: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
table.description: Occurs when trying to access an index number that does not exist in an array

table.name: ClassFormatError
table.description: Occurs when a class file cannot be accessed

table.name: ClassNotFoundException
table.description: Occurs when trying to access a class that does not exist

table.name: ConcurrentModificationException
table.description: Occurs when an element is added or removed from iterables

table.name: FileNotFoundException
table.description: Occurs when a file cannot be accessed

table.name: IncompatibleClassChangeError
table.description: Occurs when there's been a change in a base class after a child class has already been initialized

table.name: InputMismatchException
table.description: Occurs when entering wrong input (e.g. text in a numerical input)

table.name: InterruptedException
table.description: Occurs when a Thread is interrupted while waiting or sleeping

table.name: InvalidClassException
table.description: Occurs when the Serialization runtime observes a problem with a class

table.name: IOException
table.description: Occurs when an input or output operation fails

table.name: NegativeArraySizeException
table.description: Occurs when trying to create an array with negative size

table.name: NoClassDefFoundError
table.description: Occurs when the class is not found at runtime

table.name: NoSuchFieldException
table.description: Occurs when trying to access a class field or variable that does not exist

table.name: NoSuchMethodException
table.description: Occurs when trying to access a class method that does not exist

table.name: NullPointerException
table.description: Occurs when trying to access an object reference that is null

table.name: NumberFormatException
table.description: Occurs when it is not possible to convert a specified string to a numeric type

table.name: RuntimeException
table.description: Occurs when an exception occurs at runtime

table.name: StringIndexOutOfBoundsException
table.description: Occurs when trying to access a character in a String that does not exist

table.name: TypeNotPresentException
table.description: Occurs when a type cannot be found

table.name: IllegalArgumentException
table.description: Occurs when an illegal argument is passed to a method

table.name: IllegalStateException
table.description: Occurs when a method is called at an illegal time
